Having the champion get nerfed because of an item, then the next patch has the item being nerfed, but the champion receives no compensation for the first wave of nerfing, despite largely being a problem of the item, not the champion.

Pretty sure {{champion:113}} has nothing on {{champion:19}} 

Harsher nerfs, and the item that caused the problem no longer exists and the red smite was nerfed too.
{{champion:8}} Has suffered the same problem since his introduction, but I'm probably the only one who cares since self-healing/sustain is considered "cancer" by both the players and the devs alike.

Riot has apologized for creating {{champion:8}} when he got released.

The only buffs or changes you are likely to see is a rework.

That was back when Morello was in charge and made it no secret that he hated champions with reliable, useful healing. Vlad and Soraka were constantly on the receiving end of his ire, though Soraka eventually got her "rework". I was merely referring to the fact that {{champion:8}} was targeted for many nerfs before the real problem ({{item:3145}} stacking) was taken care of. He received nothing in return and his only meaningful contribution to fights now has become his amplification ult. It's entirely possible I'm biased, considering I put in a lot of time theorycrafting and proving things with Vlad that took a few months before people caught up, but no one who plays seriously these days can say Vlad is fine with a straight face.

I'm aware that a rework to his kit is likely the only thing they're going to do with him, but that's not really an answer to the problem that Riot routinely falls into the trap of doing. In fact, this really only increases their work load and player frustration. When you nerf champions because of item interactions but don't compensate the "offenders" when you finally get around to fixing the item, all you end up doing is leaving a champion in an underpowered (or sometimes unplayable) state that bothers fans of the champion and encourages Riot to pursue reworks.

I'm trying to avoid the tinfoil hat response that it's done on purpose to justify said reworks, like what happened to Karma, since at least Vlad, Sej, and Warwick are still in player rotation unlike she was. But still, it's exceptionally frustrating to see champions you enjoyed playing suffer nerfs because of item interactions and then not have those same champions get a revisioned buff pass once said items are reigned in.

Vladimir is a champion that Riot has stated they regret releasing. His kit isn't balance able. He needs an entire, full gameplay update to be back in business. Vladimir's level of frustration to play against is immense. He has two skills that cannot be dodged and two skills that are instant cast so you need either mobility or range to play around them.

Vlad has no resource bar. He sits in top lane and never leaves. He, along with Mordekaiser pre rework, is the definition of a brick wall, except that he's harder to gank.

Vlad is easy to gank before he hits level 9, when his Q finally has a low enough cooldown to be slightly better than a sick joke of an ability. On release he was far more oppressive because they gave his Q too much range, and as much as I want that range back even I know it was too high. I wasn't aware that players are still afraid of and timid against Vlad in the lane. Of course, my experience playing him means I know exactly how to play against him and if your jungler isn't willing to gank your lane early and often, that's not Vlad's fault.

In any event, I'm not getting bogged down into a discussion about Vladimir in this capacity. The point of my mentioning of him was that he's probably the best example of a champion who's been left in a weak state due to nerfing him before the problem items were nerfed, but not going back and seeing where he could be brought back up.

Jax isn't broken at all. He gets a great mid-game power spike now when he Rageblade-Gunblades but to do that he sacrifices movement speed and health that he would have from Tri-BORK. Ultimately, along with tenacity nerfs (Jax loses loads if he trades Fervor for tenacity mastery), he is now even more susceptible to being focused and chain cc'd. Doesn't matter how much damage you do, if two hard cc abilities can lock you down for death, what does it matter?

Jax is just better at what he used to do, and in return his weaknesses have been magnified. All-in-all, his 50% win percentage does go to say something. While it may not be a completely true reflection of his power, it does show he can be controlled with a little bit of common sense.

Its his issue of being designed as a melee carry that scales in both survivability and damage almost entirely from the two raw damage stats in the game. Combine that with the damage multiplier of attack speed in his passive, auto attack nullifier that triples as a damage skill and AOE stun, and semi spammable point and click mobility that doubles as as a damage dealer, and his prime damage dealing skill allowing him to proc Trinity Force(one of the best damage items in the game) perfectly, and you got a design mess on your hands. He's probably the worst design failure of a carry fighter Riot has made. His scaling is way too multiplicative, not even Win Nhao and Irelia can match it at their best. His relatively high base stats aren't helping either.

They need to tone down his multiplicative scalings and homogenize him a bit. Take away some of his low base cooldown spam or his free attack speed or his free tankiness. They're all naturally very good and scale very well with too many items. If they reduce his base numbers or scaling, they can give him conditional strengths that aren't so reliant or abusive with items to give him more acceptable highs and lows. That's my opinion at least.

I think they shouldn't take away the scalings. Maybe increase cds/mana or lower bases, but I like that he can efficiently use any item in the game. It fits with his lore in a way few champions realize.

Then they need to fully treat him like a melee carry. I suppose they'll tackle him when they do diving fighters as a whole. I'm interested in how many they're gonna convert into full melee carries, if any. Would really help flesh out the current Str(Juggernaut) and Agi(Fiora, GP, Yi, Yasuo, Trynd(?)) dilemma they got going on where they're crowding out almost every fighter when they're viable.

As I said he should be allowed to build and utilize any item in the game. Melee carries cannot build things like warmog's or sterraks. Also fighters (Jax,  Irelia) need to be kept entirely separate from melee carries (yi, trynd). They aren't the same class, they don't do they exact same thing. 

Melee carries are meant to be glass cannons with among the highest dps potentials but are kept in check by having to be melee. Typically they also get the best tools to avoid damage/death comparatively to other melee champions (yi's meditate/trynd's ult/Yasuo's windwall).

Conversely fighters are anti-carries that are tanky enough to initially survive a carries damage, mobile enough to get to them, damaging enough to kill them, but rely on items to fully achieve all of those. These champions can't build glass cannon and expect to be successful as they won't be able to survive long enough, and they can't build full tank as they won't deal enough damage.

The fighters you described are the assassin esque variant. Xin, Irelia, and Jax being three of them. They walk between the blurry line of melee carry with their defense steroids being balls of stats, massive tenacity reduction, and complete avoidance of auto attacks. There are a few more like them but those 3 stand out the most within their odd subset because of how strong they are when they're able to do what they do. 

Melee carries aren't meant to be glass cannons, juggernauts should be a big reminder of this. Melee carries are characters who're able to output enough sustained damage to hold their and a few more people's weight in a teamfight with items. That's when League's character designs start to get thrown out of whack, especially in the fighter department. Quite a few of them, mostly earlier development, were designed to be melee carries who aren't as easily dealt with in fights like Master Yi(who at the time was significantly less reliable as he is today) and Tryndamere(whose design is a failure in my opinion, even post rework). Instead of Meditate or Undying Fury, they were given a moderate amount of CC, a good amount of stats, and a lot of single target damage that isn't on a long cooldown. Can't forget the mandatory self heal and long cooldown AOE damage ult.

Assassins are anti-carries. They go in, pick off their target, go out. Fighters that can reliably do an assassin's job border the line of semi squishy melee carry because they have little in the way of getting out, so their kits are loaded with "you can do more if you stay in the moment."
